headline: Phil Heimlich to challenge Ohio's Rep. Warren Davidson for Congress; attacks Trump
author: Scott Wartman
sentences: Based on the latest maps proposed by the Ohio legislature, Davidson, a Republican from Troy, would represent a swath of western Ohio counties including a chunk of western Hamilton County all the way to the Ohio River.
"I'm running for Congress because our state and our country needs a Republican Party that supports free and fair elections and upholds the rule of law," Heimlich said in a statement.
When asked whether he thinks there are enough disillusioned Republicans in the 8th Congressional District, Heimlich said he didn't want to get into strategy.
Heimlich lives in Symmes Township in Hamilton County, which even under the latest maps, would be in Rep. Steve Chabot's 1st Congressional District.
Heimlich doesn't know whether he'll live in Davidson's district as the boundaries of the 8th Congressional District remain up in the air.
Former Cincinnati City Councilman Phil Heimlich announced Thursday he will challenge U.S. Rep. Warren Davidson in a Republican Primary.
"Congressman Davidson, like so many others in my party, has exchanged his conscience and integrity for loyalty to Donald Trump."
"It doesnâ€™t change plans in either case," said Heimlich, who also served as a Hamilton County Commissioner.
Heimlich, in his announcement, appealed to Republicans who don't support former President Donald Trump.
The U.S. Constitution requires only that U.S. House candidates live in the state they'd represent.
His district's southern border currently extends to Butler County's line with Hamilton County.
He attacked Trump's false claim the 2020 election was stolen and Davidson's support of Trump.
He will challenge Davidson no matter where the boundaries end up, Heimlich told The Enquirer.
Congressman Davidson essentially sided with the insurrection to overturn the election."
A message to Davidson's campaign manager was not immediately returned.
Trump won the 8th Congressional District in 2020 with 67% of the vote.
"The issue is, are we going to preserve our democracy?"
Heimlich doesn't see that as an issue.
"We need to protect our Democracy.
Davidson won with 69%.
Heimlich said.
